title: A Request for information about enforcement of SCC's Contract with 'Raw' for EV Chargers

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
With respect to the EV chargers provided by RAW under contract to SCC:
(a) Does SCC monitor the performance of the provider in terms of their device's periods of functioning and otherwise?
(b) If so, how is this data collected - does the Council rely on self-reporting by the company?
(c) If relevant data is available:
(i) in calendar years 2022,  2023 and first quarter 2024, how many of the relevant devices have been out of service and for what lengths of time?
(ii) how many devices  over the same period have been out of service for longer than the contract stipulates - i.e. five days?
(d) Where chargers have not been restored to functioning within the contractual requirement, what sanctions have been applied? (As an EV driver I know that many have been out of order for considerable periods - this can easily be confirmed on 'Zap Map'))
(e) On how many occasions have any sanctions been used in 2023 and first quarter 2024?
(f) If, as a recent Councillor's answer to a Public Question states (Cllr Miskell, 13 March Transport etc. Committee),  'the contract is under constant review':
(i) how many breaches of contractual requirements could or would trigger the removal of the current provider?
(ii) in such a circumstance, what would happen to the currently installed machines?
Yours faithfully,
Russell Johnson

Dear Russell Johnson,
Thank you for your request for information relating to SCC's Contract with
'Raw' for EV Chargers which we received on 03/04/2024.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 01/05/2024. Please do not hesitate to contact
us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Russell Johnson,
Thank you for your request for information relating to SCC's Contract with
'Raw' for EV Chargers which we received on 03/04/2024.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request below:
(a) Does SCC monitor the performance of the provider in terms of their
device's periods of functioning and otherwise? SCC have a back-office
system that shows when the machines are online / offline. Rest of the
information is provided monthly through RAW.
(b) If so, how is this data collected - does the Council rely on
self-reporting by the company? The data is collected and recorded in a
excel document with graphs to highlight usage / up times / repairs /
complaints, this show how much usage and how much income is set to be
received. This is presented by RAW Contracts manager to the SCC Operations
Manager that deals with the contract.
(c) If relevant data is available:
(i) in calendar years 2022, 2023 and first quarter 2024, how many of the
relevant devices have been out of service and for what lengths of time?
Please see table below.
(ii) how many devices over the same period have been out of service for
longer than the contract stipulates - i.e. five days? Please see table
below.
(d) Where chargers have not been restored to functioning within the
contractual requirement, what sanctions have been applied? (As an EV
driver I know that many have been out of order for considerable periods -
this can easily be confirmed on 'Zap Map')) Please see table below.
(e) On how many occasions have any sanctions been used in 2023 and first
quarter 2024? Please see table below.

(f) If, as a recent Councillor's answer to a Public Question states (Cllr
Miskell, 13 March Transport etc. Committee), 'the contract is under
constant review': We are working hard with the supplier to get the
machines up and running, there is a nation-wide shortage of cables due to
the high level of theft. If we do keep getting failures within the
contracts, we charge the supplier a penalty cost for not meeting KPI’s.
RAW took over from Franklin when they went out of business, so a lot of
the issues are inherited, and we do want to work on this relationship
rather than look for a new supplier.
(i) how many breaches of contractual requirements could or would trigger
the removal of the current provider? This depends on the contractual
agreement, at the moment there are small issues which are working together
to resolve.
(ii) in such a circumstance, what would happen to the currently installed
machines? Last time we changed suppliers it was Franklin going out of
business and RAW buying the contents, our understanding would be if we
used another supplier, such as Blink that supply our Fast Chargers, they
would install their own chargers and RAW would take their chargers back.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
